Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative proposal: ABI Sustaining: The Environmental-Data Automated Track Annotation (Env-DATA) system
Award.AbstractNarration:
How an animal moves through their environment reveals much about their ecology and how they respond to modern changes to the planet such as development and climate change. GPS technology embedded in collars (mammal) or backpacks (birds) has revolutionized the ability to track animals, providing more detail than ever before, sometimes in real-time. However, to make the most of these new tracking data they must be seen in the context of the world through which the animals are moving by linking their tracks to remote sensing maps showing weather and ecosystem. With both the animal and environmental data growing rapidly, there are increasing technical challenges and knowledge gaps that inhibit the widespread application of linking these types of datasets for movement ecology research. The Environmental-Data Automated Track Annotation system (Env-DATA) is a web-based tool to give direct access for movement ecology researchers to thousands of environmental datasets. It provides intuitive and easy to use graphic user interface-based access to these datasets. Env-DATA is hosted by and interfaces with Movebank, a global movement data archive, open to the broad public worldwide. Env-DATA is open and accessible to anyone. It provides easy access to already public datasets, as well and some datasets that are not otherwise open. Env-DATA provides users with tools to publish the combined environmental data along with the animal track it was used to annotate in the Movebank Data Depository. Published data sets are allocated a DOI and can be accessed and searched as electronic publications, provided an agreement from the owner of the track data. Annual workshops at the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences will reach out to new users within academia, government, and public organizations that track animals.

Env-DATA is at the cutting edge of the "contextual revolution" in movement ecology where combining analysis of movement patterns and incorporating the environmental background of the movement has become a necessary component for understanding and modeling animal movement. By providing intuitive and easy to use access to an unprecedented number of environmental datasets and variables, Env-DATA enables animal movement researchers to overcome technical challenges and knowledge gaps, and to fully utilize globally available environmental information. Env-DATA links movement tracks with environmental data from different remote-sensing and global reanalysis data providers, including NASA, NOAA, and ECMWF. Env-DATA interprets environmental variables in the correct encryption, grid, and projection systems and interpolates the data in space and time to the observed animal track locations, or a collection of comparison points or grid. Funding through this proposal will allow support of continuous on-going operations of Env-DATA, which requires regular quality control tests to detect cases where the data providers to Env-DATA may have changed the metadata, location, or access protocol. In these cases, technical support to update the system is necessary. It also requires regular availability of a user-support "help-desk". Outreach and training of new and existing users, as well as collecting first-hand feedback from users will be conducted by annual user workshops. All talks and tutorials in the workshop will be filmed and posted to the workshop website and on YouTube. Env-DATA PIs, staff, and researchers using Env-DATA will provide lectures to the broad public in the NC Museum. Undergraduate students will assist in workshop coordination and Env-DATA user support. To access Env-DATA and Movebank, visit https://www.movebank.org/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the project was to support ongoing operations and maintenance of the Environmental-Data Automated Track Annotation (Env-DATA) system. Env-DATA services animal movement research by providing access to and processing of global remote-sensing, reanalysis models, and ground-observation environmental datasets as a context for animal track observations. Env-DATA operates within Movebank.org, one of (if not the) largest animal movement data portal. This sustaining support project aimed to address three critical aspect of the on-going operations of Env-DATA:

(1) Technical support – Occasionally, data providers change the interface of the data they provide. Also, data service sources change as new satellites and models start providing key environmental observations, and older ones go offline. Keeping ongoing support through Env-DATA for annotation with the large number of environmental, human, and weather variables requires constant effort of maintaining existing data links and updating the data source of some data products.

Our outcomes regarding intellectual merit relate to this technical aspect of the project: During the course of the project, we have set up access to thousands of weather variables from the European Weather Reanalysis (ECMWF) ERA5 service, which have replaced ERA-Interim. We set up access to the VIIRS satellite products that are set to replace many of MODIS’ ocean and terrestrial ecosystem products. We set up access to the Global Precipitation Mission (GPM) data that replaced the TRMM satellite data. We updated access and changes to many specific services and variables in the Env-DATA links, including MODIS (update to version 6), OSCAR ocean currents reanalysis, North American Weather Reanalysis (NARR), and many more. We developed and released a graphic user interface (GUI) to request annotation of generic locations-time records and over gridded areas. This new GUI allow researchers of animal movement and distribution to access gridded environmental data records, and annotate modeled virtual tracks. It expanded the capabilities and applicability of Env-DATA, which previously allowed annotation only of observed tracks.   

(2) User support – We made an effort to provide an intuitive graphic user interface and easy to use programmable access. However, the large number of variables and the complexity of the services offered by the Env-DATA system mean that many of our users still needed assistance with the technical steps of using the system. During this project, a dedicated Env-DATA user-support staff, offered an on-line help desk that was accessed via e-mail, phone and teleconference, and provided hands-on help sessions to new and existing users, including webinars and tutorial sessions to individuals and institutional user groups. We helped hundreds of users by email with questions about how to use the statistical analysis tools from our workshops, submit requests, retrieve data, troubleshoot failed or incomplete requests, and interpret results. We reviewed and redesigned the documentation of the Env-DATA System (www.movebank.org/cms/movebank-content/env-data).

(3) Broader Impact - Outreach to new potential users is necessary to make the potential benefits of the system known within the community, and to allow the system to reach its full potential in servicing the broader science community. During the project, we focused on broadening the user base of Env-DATA. We have conducted three user workshops, targeting audience of students and early career researchers. The workshops focused on training for using Env-DATA to obtain environmental information for analysis of animal movement tracks, and conducting statistical analysis and modeling of joined environmental-movement data. More than 100 people attended the workshops. The workshop lectures were recorded and made available online (https://movebankworkshopraleighnc.netlify.app/).

We have established the Movebank archive as a form of collaborative data portal to allow secure data sharing across a broad group of users with a common interest. An archive allows a single-point access to a collection of animal movement studies from multiple users, while maintaining data ownership and permissions. A Movebank archive supports public data discovery, preserves fundamental baseline data for the future, and facilitates efficient collaborative data analysis. Archives are an effective data sharing approach particularly among groups of broad interests, composed of land and wildlife managers, educators, animal movement researchers and data analysts. Our first archive was the Arctic Animal Movement Archive (AAMA) a growing collection of more than 200 standardized terrestrial and marine animal tracking studies from 1991 to the present, and was published in the journal Science (https://science.sciencemag.org/content/370/6517/712). We worked with additional users to propose other archives, such as the Yukon-to-Yellowstone Migration Corridor.

Overall, our ongoing activities enabled continuous growth of the Env-DATA user base. Between 2019-04-01 and 2020-10-31, 603,208 artifact files were accessed 62,825,028 times. Clustering the access records in 5-min steps gives roughly 10,000 “access bursts” (~17/day), providing an approximate estimate of annotation requests made within and outside of the Movebank GUI. Over this same time interval, 3,084 annotation requests were submitted through the Movebank GUI, comprising 47,000 animals/tags that have been submitted by 304 unique users.
